p: Peru is one of the main international destinations for culinary holidays [ 1– 3]. The variety of endemic edible products from the highlands, as well as from the Peruvian Amazon, together with a thriving gastronomic industry in the city of Lima has made Peru a leading nation in terms of innovation in the food sector. Despite the buoyancy of its food sector, as well as high economic growth rates since the year 2000, there are still severe cases of child malnourishment in many regions, and in impoverished districts average diets are based on a very limited variety of food basket products [ 4– 5]. According to the World Food Programme, over 4% of Peruvians still lived, as of 2014, in extreme poverty, and approximately 5.2 million people are highly exposed to food insecurity [ 6], in a country located in a high seismic activity zone, and with cyclical droughts and floods [ 7– 8].
